SENT.plain: CONTEXT: High plasmatic homocysteine levels have been associated with arterial and venous thrombosis
The C677T methylene tetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene mutation is one of the known causes for high homocysteine levels in plasma
Anticardiolipin antibody (ACA) is also associated with thrombosis and, along with other clinical complications such as recurrent abortion and stillbirth, is part of the antiphospholipid syndrome
CASE REPORT: A 19-year-old woman with two gestations and one parity (G2P1) had exhibited deep venous thrombosis in her previous puerperal period
Investigation of thrombophilic factors revealed ACA-IgM and heterozygous C677T mutation in the MTHFR gene
Lupus anticoagulant, protein C, protein S and antithrombin III deficiencies, and Leiden factor V and the G20210A mutation in the prothrombin gene, were not detected
The patient received 55,000 IU of subcutaneous heparin daily, from the 15th to the 36th week of pregnancy, when vaginal delivery took place
There were no clinical complications during the puerperal period and she was discharged three days after delivery, while still using oral anticoagulants
